context: The Aerospace Mechanics Research Center (AMReC) at the University of Colorado Boulder focuses on the analysis of fluids, structures, and materials for designing complex, high-performance aerospace systems, including developing innovative computational techniques and applying them to novel aerospace problems.
chunk_text: the Ann and H.J. Smead Aerospace Engineering Sciences Department , the Aerospace Mechanics Research Center (AMReC) is concerned with the analysis of fluids, structures and materials for the design of complex, high-performance engineered systems, predominantly for aeronautical and space applications. This includes the development of innovative computational analysis and design techniques as well as the application of these techniques and methods to novel, exciting aerospace problems. Reducing

context: The Aerospace Mechanics Research Center at the University of Colorado Boulder conducts research on the analysis of fluids, structures, and materials for the design of complex, high-performance engineered systems, including the development of innovative computational analysis and design techniques. This chunk describes a specific research project on reducing flow drag by using crystals to delay laminar-to-turbulent transition.
chunk_text: to novel, exciting aerospace problems. Reducing Flow Drag by Crystals Profs. Hussein and Biringen established a new paradigm for passive flow stabilization to delay laminar-to-turbulent transition and reduce skin-friction drag. Their concept is based on extending the phenomenon of wave destructive interferences–traditionally observed only in solids–to the flow field. This novel approach is realized by interfacing the flow with an enlarged and carefully tuned crystal, also known as a phononic

context: The document discusses the research activities of the Aerospace Mechanics Research Center (AMReC) at the University of Colorado Boulder, including projects on flow stabilization using phononic materials, the mechanics of high strain composites, and design optimization across multiple length scales.
chunk_text: carefully tuned crystal, also known as a phononic material. [Project funded by NSF] Hussein, M.I., Biringen, S., Bilal, O.R., and Kucala, A. “Flow stabilization by subsurface phonons,” Proceedings of the Royal Society A, 471, 20140928. 2015. Mechanics of High Strain Composites A collaboration between Prof. López Jiménez and Roccor, funded by the AFRL, combines experiments and analysis to predict the failure properties of high strain composites, with application to deployable space structures.

context: The Aerospace Mechanics Research Center at the University of Colorado Boulder conducts research on various topics, including the mechanics of high strain composites and design optimization across multiple length scales. This chunk discusses the center's work on applying these techniques to deployable space structures and developing scalable algorithms for multi-physics design optimization.
chunk_text: with application to deployable space structures. Design Optimization Across 8+ Length Scales A DARPA funded grant lead by Profs. Maute, Doosan, and Evans focuses on the development of scalable algorithms for design optimization of multi-physics systems across multiple length scales and in the presence of uncertainty. context: The Aerospace Mechanics Research Center at the University of Colorado Boulder conducts research on various topics related to aerospace engineering, including atmospheric boundary layer turbulence, data-driven turbulence modeling, and simulation of complex systems.
chunk_text: responses to weather events Application to nonsteady aerodynamic response of wind turbines to atmospheric turbulence Data-Driven Turbulence Modeling and Simulation An NSF funded grant lead by Profs. Jansen and Evans and supported by Boeing Senior Fellow Dr. Spalart focuses on the development of improved prediction technologies for separated turbulent flows by leveraging advances in data science and machine learning and a spectrum of modeling and simulation paradigms spanning RANS, DES, LES, and

context: The document discusses the research activities of the Aerospace Mechanics Research Center (AMReC) at the University of Colorado Boulder, including projects on flow stabilization, high strain composites, design optimization, turbulence modeling, and simulation of catastrophic flooding events.
chunk_text: simulation paradigms spanning RANS, DES, LES, and DNS. From Geospatial Data Sources to Simulation of Catastrophic Flooding Events A University of Colorado Boulder funded grant lead by Prof. Evans and supported by Prof. Farmer of the Department Geography focuses on the development of algorithms for the automated generation of geophysical fluid dynamics models from incomplete, noisy, and disparate geospatial data sources. Software Tools for Immersive Simulation An NSF funded grant lead by Profs.

context: The Aerospace Mechanics Research Center at the University of Colorado Boulder is conducting research on various topics, including the development of software tools for immersive simulation, which allows analysts to interact with and modify system parameters during parallel simulations.
chunk_text: Simulation An NSF funded grant lead by Profs. Jansen, Doostan, Evans, and Maute focuses on the creation of software tools to enable immersive simulation, a new simulation paradigm which allows analysts to not only visualize system response but also interact with their system and modify boundary conditions, material, and geometry parameters during an ongoing massively parallel simulation.
